newsitem.title: INDIA: Oman-India gas pipeline project on, says official.
newsitem.headline: Oman-India gas pipeline project on, says official.

text.p: The Oman-India subsea natural gas pipeline project has not been abandoned, the chairman of India's leading natural gas company said.
"We are hopeful about it," C.R. Prasad, chairman and managing director of the state-run Gas Authority of India Ltd (GAIL) told a conference on deep water exploration on Saturday.
"A lot of technical issues are already resolved," he said.
"From our side it is not abandoned," Prasad said when asked about news reports that Oman had abandoned the project over technical considerations.
Oman had spent over $60 million in feasibility studies.
India was also pursuing the Iran-India gas pipeline project, Prasad said. GAIL is India's leading natural gas supplier.
A pipeline to bring gas from countries east of India was also being considered, he said.

"Against a demand of 200 million cubic metres of gas, we are supplying only 50 million," Prasad said. To bridge the gap, GAIL planned to build a multi-billion dollar network of liquified natural gas (LNG) terminals along the coast, he said.
Seventeen international firms has put in bids for building the terminals coming up along the eastern and western coast.
Prasad said GAIL was joining hands with the state-run Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corporation for deep water exploration off India's coast for oil and natural gas.
"ONGC has done extensive surveys of India's deep waters and some good prospects have emerged," he said without elaborating.
"I expect a sizeable future production to come from deep waters," Prasad told India's first deep water exploration seminar. -- Bombay newsroom +91-22-265 9000
